title: Musical Engagement of Brain LObes in Alzheimer's Disease Patients StudY
description_brief: This is a randomized, cross-over study to measure global and clinical impact and level of arousal in subjects suffering from moderate to severe Alzheimer's disease when exposed to emotionally impactful music compared to control intervention.
description_detailed: In partnership with the study partner (a person who spends 10 hours or more a week with the subject and can reliably report on the subject's condition), three tunes will be chosen for the purposes of the study. The tunes chosen will need to be related to a past meaningful, positive experience of the subject, as determined by the subject and the subject's study partner. The pieces will be restricted in duration to between 1.5 and 2 minutes each. A piece will be chosen at random and will be saved on a portable device, and subjects will be asked to listen to the melody using high quality, over-ear headphones. The total exposure time will be 10 minutes each hour over a three-hour period. The melody will be repeated as many times as necessary to complete the 10-minute period. The control intervention will involve listening to nature sounds at the same duration and administration scheme. Functional magnetic resonance imaging will be used to identify how brain networks are modulated via exposure to this music and how they associate with the clinical findings.

participantFlowModule.preAssignmentDetails: No significant events in the study occured after participant enrollment and prior to assignment of participants to an arm or group.
participantFlowModule.recruitmentDetails: The PI contacted physicians in the Charleston, South Carolina area to inform them about the study and request patient referrals of potential participants. Once a referral was made, the potential participant was contacted by the PI via telephone, the study was described, and if the participant and study partner expressed interest in the study, the study coordinator scheduled them for a Screening Visit.

groups.title: Preferred Music - Visit 1, Nature Sounds - Visit 2
groups.description:
Preferred Music: Participants will listen to selected music using over-ear headphones delivered as 10-minute segments at the top of each hour over the course of 3 hours

Nature Sounds: Participants will listen to nature sounds using over-ear headphones delivered as 10-minute segments at the top of each hour over the course of 3 hours

categories.title: Native Hawaiian or Other Pacific Islander

outcomeMeasures.title: Changes in Intervention Response as Evaluated by the Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC)
outcomeMeasures.description: This is a 7-item score ranging from "markedly worse" to "markedly improved". It is assessed by the study clinician who interviews both participant and makes an informed judgment how to incorporate their input.
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All 10 participants were assessed after being exposed to preferred music (PM) and nature sounds (NS) and rated on the Clinical Global Impression of Change (CGIC).

outcomeMeasures.title: Change in Level of Arousal as Evaluated by the Stanford Sleepiness Scale (SSS)
outcomeMeasures.description: Participants will provide a self-assessed scoring of their level of arousal on a scale of 1-7 ranging from "Feeling active, vital, alert, or wide awake" to "No longer fighting sleep, sleep onset soon; having dream-like thoughts".
outcomeMeasures.populationDescription: All 10 participants were assessed after being exposed to preferred music (PM) and nature sounds (NS) and rated on the Stanford Sleepiness Scale (SSS).

classes.title: 1 - Feeling active, vital, alert, or wide awake - Rating 1
2 - Functioning at high levels, but not at peak - Rating 1
3 - Awake, but relaxed; responsive, but not fully alert - Rating 1
5 - Foggy; losing interest in staying awake; slowed down - Rating 1
6 - Sleepy, woozy, fighting sleep; prefer to lie down - Rating 1
7 - No longer fighting sleep; sleep onset soon - Rating 1
1 - Feeling active, vital, alert, or wide awake - Rating 2
2 - Functioning at high levels, but not at peak - Rating 2
3 - Awake, but relaxed; responsive, but not fully alert - Rating 2
5 - Foggy; losing interest in staying awake; slowed down - Rating 2
6 - Sleepy, woozy, fighting sleep; prefer to lie down - Rating 2
7 - No longer fighting sleep; sleep onset soon - Rating 2

adverseEventsModule.description: Adverse events were not separated by intervention because no events occurred during the administration of either the experimental or control conditions. All adverse events reported occurred outside of the study visits and were determined to be unrelated to the study interventions. These events were monitored and documented in accordance with protocol guidelines and were not associated with the auditory exposures.

explanation_target: Reason: The intervention described is exposure to emotionally impactful (preferred) music versus a control (nature sounds) in a randomized cross-over design — a behavioral/non‑pharmacologic music intervention aimed at measuring arousal and global clinical impact, not a drug or biologic. citeturn0search1turn0search0

Act (key details extracted): The trial (MELODY, ClinicalTrials.gov ID NCT05309369) enrolled subjects with moderate–severe Alzheimer’s disease and compared Preferred Music (PM) to Nature Sounds (NS) delivered via headphones; outcomes included a modified ADCS‑CGIC and brain imaging (fMRI) to evaluate network connectivity. This is explicitly a behavioral/music therapy study, not a pharmacologic agent. citeturn0search0turn0search1

Reflect: Classification check against definitions — it is not a biologic (no monoclonal antibody/vaccine), not a small molecule, not a pharmacologic cognitive enhancer, and not an intervention primarily targeting neuropsychiatric symptoms with a drug. Although music interventions can produce cognitive/clinical benefits, they are non‑drug behavioral therapies; therefore the correct category per the provided list is 'N/A'. For context, systematic reviews and imaging studies support music as a non‑pharmacologic intervention that can modulate cognition and brain networks in AD. citeturn0search3turn0search4
